title: Kaja Rogulj
text:
Kaja Rogulj (born 15 June 1986) is a retired <a href="Croats">Croatian</a> <a href="association%20football">football</a> player who played as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a>.
Club career.
Rogulj started his football career at the <a href="NK%20B%C5%A0K%20Zmaj%20Blato">NK BŠK Zmaj Blato</a> on the island of <a href="Kor%C4%8Dula">Korčula</a>, before moving to the <a href="HNK%20Hajduk%20Split">HNK Hajduk Split</a>, where he spent most of his formative years in a generation that featured, among others, <a href="Drago%20Gabri%C4%87">Drago Gabrić</a> and <a href="Tomislav%20Bu%C5%A1i%C4%87">Tomislav Bušić</a>. In 2003, however, he moved on to the <a href="NK%20Omi%C5%A1">NK Omiš</a> U-19 team, where he spent the following two years.
He played his first senior team matches, however, in <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, at <a href="NK%20Posu%C5%A1je">NK Posušje</a> where he moved in 2005, and where he spent, apart from a half-season stint at <a href="HNK%20Segesta">HNK Segesta</a> the following three years.
In 2008, he moved back to <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>, to <a href="NK%20Slaven%20Belupo">NK Slaven Belupo</a>, featuring soon in a 2-1 aggregate <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup second qualifying round</a> upset against <a href="Aris%20Thessaloniki%20FC">Aris Thessaloniki FC</a> before being eliminated by <a href="PFC%20CSKA%20Moscow">CSKA Moscow</a>. On 3 March 2009, in a match against <a href="Dinamo%20Zagreb">Dinamo Zagreb</a> Kaja received an instant <a href="penalty%20card">red card</a> after a particularly nasty tackle on <a href="Mario%20Mand%C5%BEuki%C4%87">Mario Mandžukić</a>. Later on, he was suspended for two games and had to pay a fine of around <a href="%E2%82%AC">€</a>700. He remained a first team regular until the end of his stint at <a href="NK%20Slaven%20Belupo">Slaven</a>, and featured in the <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2009–10 UEFA Europa League</a> qualifiers, until his team was eliminated by <a href="Troms%C3%B8%20IL">Tromsø IL</a>.
In the summer of 2011, he moved to <a href="FK%20Austria%20Wien">Austria Wien</a>, signing a 2+1 year contract, with director <a href="Thomas%20Parits">Thomas Parits</a> praising his jumping, timing and tackling. After a rocky first season, he established himself as a first-team player in the 2012/13 season, winning the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20Austrian%20Football%20Bundesliga">2012–13 Austrian Football Bundesliga</a> with his club, and making his debut in the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> in 2013. After eliminating <a href="GNK%20Dinamo%20Zagreb">GNK Dinamo Zagreb</a> with 4-3 on aggregate, Rogulj played in all group matches against <a href="FC%20Zenit%20Saint%20Petersburg">Zenit Staint Petersburg</a>, <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Madrid">Atlético Madrid</a> and <a href="FC%20Porto">FC Porto</a> but one.
In the summer of 2014, he moved on to the <a href="Switzerland">Swiss</a> team <a href="FC%20Luzern">FC Luzern</a>.
In 30 October 2017, he became a member of <a href="FK%20%C5%BDalgiris">FK Žalgiris</a> in Lithuania.
Rogulj retired at the end of the 2018–19 season.
